BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Natural avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Very large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs formed by the storm force wind are prone to triggering in all aspects above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in areas close to the tree line. Natural avalanches are to be expected, this applies especially during the course of the night. In particular on north and east facing slopes avalanches can be released in the various layers of new snow and reach large size. Additionally in very isolated cases avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach very large size. With the end of the intense snowfall, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

In addition a substantial danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A lot of new snow above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be storm force. As a consequence of the westerly wind the already large wind slabs will increase in size once again. The various wind slabs have bonded insufficiently with each other and the old snowpack. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a slow decrease in the danger of dry avalanches. The new snow and wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. An increasing number of gliding avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming. As a consequence of solar radiation more frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Down to 1200 m snow has fallen in some regions. The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On Saturday the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. In particular on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in the various wind slab layers and reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was strong. The soft wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and in particular the sometimes large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The fresh wind slabs can especially at their margins be released very easily. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach large size in isolated cases. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. Individual loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially on extremely steep slopes.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

The conditions are sometimes critical for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on steep sunny slopes. Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
Until Saturday the wind will be strong. In particular transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: Fresh wind slabs can be released easily. Caution is to be exercised on steep slopes below approximately 2600 m. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
The weather will be very mild in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. Some medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A little new snow. The actual quantities of new snow that have fallen are impossible to define.
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
More recent wind slabs are to be found especially areas not adjacent to ridgelines.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase a little at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The fresh wind slabs can especially at their margins be released very easily. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach medium size.
The conditions are precarious for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The storm force wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a storm force northwesterly wind, mostly small wind slabs formed in the last two days. In particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. Between approximately 2400 and 3000 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of the wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind from northerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The violent wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
Until Saturday the wind will be strong. In particular transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: Fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily, especially on very steep shady slopes.
The weather will be very mild in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. Some small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A little new snow. The actual quantities of new snow that have fallen are impossible to define. More recent wind slabs are to be found especially areas not adjacent to ridgelines. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase a little at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Above approximately 2500 m snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to significant settling of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. In some localities up to 10 cm of snow has fallen. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Hardly any small avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. They are very small. The weather conditions from the early morning will give rise to moistening of the old snowpack. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already be soft in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.
